spur.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: a fact or event that makes you try harder to do something
spur.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: The crowd’s reaction only acted as a spur.
It provided the spur to further research.
spur.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: a sharp pointed object on the heel of a rider’s boot which is used to encourage a horse to go faster
spur.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: a piece of high ground which sticks out from the side of a hill or mountain
spur.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: a railway track or road that goes away from a main line or road
spur.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: to encourage someone or make them want to do something
spur.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: The band were spurred on by the success of their last two singles.
It was an article in the local newspaper which finally spurred him into action.
His misfortunes spurred him to write.
the coach who spurred him on to Olympic success
spur.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: to make an improvement or change happen faster
spur.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: Lower taxes would spur investment and help economic growth.
spur.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: to encourage a horse to go faster, especially by pushing it with special points on the heels of your boots
